content.title: Essential Enclosure Requirements for Mourning Geckos
content.content: Mourning geckos are tiny arboreal lizards native to tropical rainforests across the South Pacific, Central America, and Hawaii. At only 4 inches long, these social geckos require vertical climbing space and MUST be housed in groups. Proper enclosure setup is critical for this species' wellbeing, as they are naturally communal and rely on companions for normal behavior.

Mourning geckos are obligate social animals and must NEVER be housed alone. The absolute minimum group size is 2 geckos, with 3-4 being ideal. Because they are arboreal (tree-dwelling), vertical space is more important than floor space. Height allows them to establish territories at different levels and maximize climbing opportunities.

content.content: Plan for population growth! All mourning geckos are female and reproduce via parthenogenesis (no males needed). Each gecko can lay 2 eggs every 4-6 weeks, and offspring are fertile within 6-8 months. Start with adequate space or prepare to upgrade.

Mourning geckos require high humidity (60-80%) and stable temperatures. Glass front-opening terrariums are ideal because they retain humidity better than screen cages while still allowing necessary ventilation.

content.content: Recommended: Glass front-opening terrarium (e.g., Exo Terra, Zoo Med) with screen top for ventilation. Ensure doors close securely - mourning geckos are escape artists!

Maximize vertical climbing space at all levels. Mourning geckos utilize the entire enclosure height and need branches, vines, and foliage from bottom to top. The warmest area should be near the top (under the heat lamp), with cooler zones toward the bottom.

content.text: Zone Layout Template (12°12°18 enclosure):

rows: Horizontal branches, leaf canopy, feeding ledge
Diagonal branches, vines, cork bark hides
Ground cover, leaf litter, humid hides

content.content: Create multiple climbing pathways at each level so geckos can move vertically without conflict. Social doesn't mean they won't compete for prime basking spots!
Follow this order for efficient setup:

items: Substrate layer: Add 2-4 inches of tropical substrate mix (60% organic topsoil + 40% coconut fiber), then top with leaf litter
Background structures: Position largest branches and cork bark against back and side walls, angling from bottom to top
Mid-enclosure features: Add diagonal branches and vines creating climbing pathways at multiple heights
Foliage placement: Distribute plants evenly (top, middle, bottom) ensuring each level has cover
Feeding stations: Attach magnetic ledges at different heights to reduce competition during feeding
Equipment mounting: Place heat lamp over one upper corner (not center), UVB bulb on side of hood, probe placement mid-height
Testing phase: Run equipment for 24-48 hours before adding geckos, adjust heat dimmer to achieve 80-85°F basking spot

content.content: CRITICAL: Basking temperature must NOT exceed 85°F. Temperatures above 85°F can cause heat stress and death. Use a dimmer to fine-tune wattage - do not rely on guessing bulb size!

content.text: Mistakes to Avoid:

rows: Severe stress, abnormal behavior, shortened lifespan
Use glass terrarium with screen top only
Start with 25w + dimmer, measure with temp gun
Weak bones, egg binding, metabolic issues
Provide 5.0 UVB even though they're nocturnal
Start larger or prepare to upgrade

content.content: Pro tip: Consider bioactive substrate from the start. With cleanup crew (springtails and dwarf isopods), you'll only need to spot clean and never do full substrate changes!
